Description: A circular stamp for a jar-stopper, with an applied stubby cylindrical grip, pierced by a horizontal hole; part is broken away. It has an incuse pattern: within a circle are three facing standing male figures, two with both arms akimbo, one with his right hand stretched out over a square object, apparently a chest. Each has a nimbus, and no doubt are saints; the centre and largest figure has an uncertain device above his nimbus. Between the heads is an equal-armed cross. Drapery falls behind each figure, apparently from their shoulders, like a cloak, and below them is a branch-pattern with a stud at each end. Four more studs are placed at the right side; the left side is broken away. Pressed over a modelled form. Red-brown Nile silt with a brown core and some white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Late Roman, about AD 500-700. Comparanda: Quibell and Thompson 1912: pl. xlvi:2 is a jar-stopper with a single figure quite near to our three figures, and said to be Saint Menas; it comes from the Monastery of Apa Jeremias at Saqqara and is dated between AD 500 and 850. Another sealing with a single, nimbed, figure comes from Akoris in Middle Egypt (Kawanishi 1995: 225, fig. 154:2: context early seventh century AD). See also a double-sided stamp with two figures (Cosmas and Damien?) similar to our three, and Saint Menas on the second side (Heide and Thiel 2004: 135, no. iii.2.9, dated sixth to seventh century AD).
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3606)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
